CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph:

1. POBDTPD (mentioned twice)
2. PEBDTPD (mentioned twice)
3. PC 70 BM (mentioned twice)
4. ITO (mentioned once)
5. PSS (mentioned once)
6. TiO2 (mentioned once)
7. Al (mentioned once)

These are the entities that are referred to by their full names throughout the paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the entities that refer to "Material Name" in the paragraph:

1. POBDTPD
2. PEBDTPD
3. PC 70 BM

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the valid entities that refer to "Material Name" in the paragraph:

| Material Name |
| --- |
| POBDTPD |
| PEBDTPD |
| PC 70 BM |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

1. POBDTPD:
 * Donor: dialkoxybenzodithiophene (BDT)
 * Acceptor: N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
2. PEBDTPD:
 * Donor: dialkoxybenzodithiophene (BDT)
 * Acceptor: N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD)
3. PC 70 BM:
 * Polymer: poly[70% phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester] (PC 70 BM)
4. PC 60 BM:
 * Polymer: poly[60% phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester] (PC 60 BM)
5. ITO:
 * Indium tin oxide (ITO)
6. PEDOT:
 * Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT)
7. PSS:
 * Polystyrene sulfonate (PSS)
8. TiO2:
 * Titanium dioxide (TiO2)
9. Al:
 * Aluminum (Al)

Note: Some of these materials have multiple names, but I have listed the most common or widely used names for each material.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

Of course! Here are the relevant entities from the text that refer to the property name of a material:

1. POBDTPD
2. PEBDTPD
3. PC 70 BM
4. PC 60 BM

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's go through the values of the material properties mentioned in the paragraph:

1. Values of the material properties for POBDTPD:
 * Donor energy level (HOMO): -5.3 eV
 * Acceptor energy level (LUMO): -4.0 eV
 * Band gap: ∼ 900 nm
 * Power conversion efficiency (PCE): 4.7%
 * Open-circuit voltage (V oc): 0.70 V
 * Short-circuit current density (J sc): 10.6 mA/cm^2
 * Fill factor (FF): 0.64
2. Values of the material properties for PEBDTPD:
 * Donor energy level (HOMO): -5.3 eV
 * Acceptor energy level (LUMO): -4.0 eV
 * Band gap: ∼ 900 nm
 * Power conversion efficiency (PCE): 5.3%
 * Open-circuit voltage (V oc): 0.72 V
 * Short-circuit current density (J sc): 13.5 mA/cm^2
 * Fill factor (FF): 0.54
3. Other values mentioned in the paragraph:
 * Solar spectrum absorption range: ∼ 900 nm
 * Fullerene derivatives used in the photoactive layer: [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PC 60 BM) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester (PC 70 BM)
 * Desirable characteristics for high power conversion efficiency (PCE) in PSCs: good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum, optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron-acceptor fullerene derivatives, formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer, and provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

Sure, here are the relevant entities that refer to the value of material properties in the provided text:

1. "4.7% PCE" - This refers to the power conversion efficiency of the solar cell.
2. "10.6 mA/cm^2" - This refers to the short-circuit current density of the solar cell.
3. "13.5 mA/cm^2" - This refers to the short-circuit current density of the solar cell.
4. "0.64" - This refers to the fill factor of the solar cell.
